On the east, northeast, north, northwest, and west sides of the cylindrical mount are the remainder of the figures<ref name="ConfederatesHere" /><ref name="PayTribute" /> in high relief.<ref name="ArriveUnveiling" /> These figures are intended to represent the sacrifices, devotion, and heroism of all social classes of people in the Confederacy.<ref name="ArriveUnveiling" /> The figures depict: *A military officer kissing his infant child, who is held in the arms of a weeping [[Mammy archetype|black mammy]] while another child clings to her skirts;<ref name="Sedore115" /><ref name="Herbert66">Herbert, p. 66.</ref> *A shirtless blacksmith leaving his [[anvil]] and tools behind as his sorrowful wife looks on;<ref name="Sedore115" /><ref name="Herbert66" /> *A clergyman and his grieving wife saying goodbye to their teenage son (who has enlisted);<ref name="Herbert66" /> and *A young lady binding a sword and sash onto her beau.<ref name="Sedore115" /><ref name="Herbert67" />
The inclusion of the "faithful black servants" was purposeful.<ref name="Gibson193" /> Sculptor Moses Ezekiel included them because he wanted to undermine what he called the "lies" told about the South and slavery in [[Harriett Beecher Stowe]]'s 1852 novel ''[[Uncle Tom's Cabin]]'' and wished to rewrite history "correctly" (his word) to depict black slaves' support for the Confederate cause.<ref name="Herbert66" />
An [[oak]] tree spreads its branches behind the couple and their son and the blacksmith's family. It represents the support family lends to the Confederate cause, as well as the strength of Confederate families.<ref name="Herbert67">Herbert, p. 67.</ref>
===Base=== [[File:Confederate Monument - S frieze detail - Arlington National Cemetery - 2011.JPG|thumb|The fallen figure of a woman, also representing "The South", leans on a shield emblazoned with the words "The Constitution" as a symbol of what the UDC believed the South fought for.]] [[File:Confederate Monument - SW shields - Arlington National Cemetery - 2011.JPG|thumb|Cinerary urns and shields bearing the coat of arms of each state support the topmost figure on the memorial.]] The 32 life-size figures stand on an irregular octagonal base. The front (or south-facing side) of this base depicts the Great Seal of the Confederacy in low relief.<ref name="Sedore114" /> In raised letters below the seal are the following words:<ref name="PayTribute" /> <blockquote>TO OUR DEAD HEROES<br> BY<br> THE UNITED DAUGHTERS<br> OF THE CONFEDERACY<br> VICTRIX CAUSA DIIS<br> PLACUIT SED VICTA CATON </blockquote>This [[Latin]] phrase means: "The Victorious Cause was Pleasing to the Gods, But the Lost Cause Pleased Cato." It is a quotation from the poem ''[[Pharsalia]]'' by the ancient Roman poet [[Lucan (poet)|Lucan]]. It refers to the attempt by the Roman Senator [[Pompey]] to prevent [[Julius Caesar]] from becoming dictator of Rome in 49 BC. Although he lost, Pompey's actions pleased the great philosopher and statesman [[Cato the Younger|Cato]] (who was noted for his moral integrity).<ref>Sedore, p. 115.</ref>
On the north face of the memorial in raised letters are the following words:<ref name="Sedore115" /><ref name="ArriveUnveiling" /><ref>Wilson, p. 41-42; Herbert, p. 67-68.</ref> <blockquote>NOT FOR FAME OR REWARD<br> NOT FOR PLACE OR FOR RANK<br> NOT LURED BY AMBITION<br> OR GOADED BY NECESSITY<br> BUT IN SIMPLE<br> OBEDIENCE TO DUTY<br> AS THEY UNDERSTOOD IT<br> THESE MEN SUFFERED ALL<br> SACRIFICED ALL<br> DARED ALL — AND DIED<br> RANDOLPH HARRISON MCKIM</blockquote>
On the northwest face of the octagonal base, in raised letters, are the words:<ref name="Sedore115" /> <blockquote>M. Ezekiel * Sculptor<br> Rome MCMXII</blockquote>
On the northeast face of the octagonal base, in raised letters, are the words:<ref name="Sedore115" /> <blockquote>MADE BY<br> AKTIEN-GESELLSCHAFT GLADENBECK<br> BRONZE FOUNDERY<br> BERLIN-FRIEDRICHSHAGEN-GERMANY</blockquote>
The east and west sides of the octagonal base are flanked by pedestals, on top of which are urn-like lamps topped with "eternal flames" of bronze.<ref name="Cox154" />
===Critical assessment=== The ''Washington Post'' lauded the memorial when it was unveiled. It was effusive in its praise for the monument's focus on peace and the future, its emphasis on the South's fight for constitutional rights and not slavery, and its repetitive images focusing on the sacrifices made by the heroic common soldier.<ref name="ArriveUnveiling" /> Unnamed European art critics cited by ''The Sunday Star'' newspaper said it was "a marvel of facial expression and allegorically perfect".<ref>"Confederate Memorial Sculptor Arrives Here." ''The Sunday Star.'' May 31, 1914.</ref> Colonel William Couper, a faculty member at the Virginia Military Institute (VMI), praised it in 1933 as "magnificent and impressive".<ref>Couper, p. 67.</ref>
Modern critics have been somewhat more equivocal. Keith Gibson, executive director of the VMI museum system, says the Confederate Memorial is a "superb example of Ezekiel's style and imagery", and one of the artist's most significant works.<ref name="Gibson193" /> Gibson nevertheless faults the memorial for its static posing and "hard contours".<ref name="Gibson193" /> Historian Katherine Allamong Jacob, however, notes that while the memorial is "intensely dramatic" it is also "not a little sentimental".<ref>Jacob, p. 166-167.</ref> In 2007, ''Washington Post'' reporter Linda Wheeler found the memorial ornate and romantic and praised it as a vivid reflection of Victorian artistic taste.<ref name="Wheeler" /> Kirk Savage, associate professor of art history and architecture at the [[University of Pittsburgh]], criticizes the memorial for being "clearly the product of white supremacist thinking and practice".<ref name="Savage183">Savage, p. 183.</ref> Historian Erika Lee Doss agrees, calling it a "pro-Southern textbook".<ref>Doss, p. 11.</ref>
==History of the memorial== In August 1915, Secretary of War [[Lindley Miller Garrison]] determined that the Confederate Monument should be cared for by the federal government under the authority granted by the Act of June 8, 1906.<ref>"To Care for Monuments." ''Washington Post.'' August 15, 1915.</ref>
As of November 2013, the Confederate Memorial remains one of three sites at Arlington National Cemetery mentioned by name in the ''[[Code of Federal Regulations]]'' where public memorial services may be conducted. (The others are the Memorial Amphitheater and the [[John F. Kennedy Eternal Flame|John F. Kennedy Grave]].)<ref>[http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/docs/ANC_Visitors_Rules.pdf Title 32: National Defense. Part 553—Army National Cemeteries. §553.22 (h)(3)(i). Code of Federal Regulations. 2013.] Accessed 2013-11-05.</ref>
===Final financial issues=== A total of $56,262.01 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|56262|1914}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars) was raised by the UDC for the memorial by November 1914.<ref name="21UDC279" /> But the $40,000 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|40000|1914}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars) budgeted for design and casting of the monument fell short of the actual cost. Ezekiel was forced to spend about $5,000 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|5000|1914}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars)<ref name="21UDC271" /> of his own funds casting the piece, as the money paid to him barely covered the cost of materials.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=zGxUAAAAYAAJ&dq=Eighteenth%20convention%20United%20Daughters&pg=PA345#v=onepage&q&f=false United Daughters of the Confederacy, ''Minutes of the Twentieth Annual Convention...'', p. 345.] Accessed 2013-10-30.</ref>
Many UDC leaders felt fundraising should continue since the Little Rock convention of 1910 had implicitly promised to pay Ezekiel more money. The resolution which enlarged the memorial and increased the amount of money budgeted for it read: "...that the monument in Washington shall cost not less than $50,000, with the hopes of $75,000, and that a contract be made to this effect...".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=em5LAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA272&ots=2lynqWWQDD&dq=%22Moses%20Ezekiel%22%20%2475%2C000&pg=PA272#v=onepage&q=%22Moses%20Ezekiel%22%20$75,000&f=false United Daughters of the Confederacy, ''Minutes of the Twenty-First Annual Convention...'', p. 272.] Accessed 2013-10-30.</ref> Although Ezekiel declined to press the issue, UDC leaders felt morally bound to try to pay him the additional $25,000 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|25000|1914}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars). In November 1914, with nearly all the costs of the memorial, its erection, and dedication paid, there remained a memorial fund balance of $1,770.92 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|1771|1914}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars). This money was paid to Ezekiel.<ref name="21UDC271">[https://books.google.com/books?id=N30VAQAAMAAJ&dq=Minutes%20convention%20%22United%20Daughters%22%20volume%2018&pg=RA1-PA271#v=onepage&q&f=false United Daughters of the Confederacy, ''Minutes of the Twenty-First Annual Convention...'', p. 271.] Accessed 2013-10-30.</ref><ref name="CV128">[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZEEOAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Confederate%20Memorial%22%20Ezekiel&pg=PA228#v=onepage&q=%22Confederate%20Memorial%22%20Ezekiel&f=false "United Daughters of the Confederacy." ''Confederate Veteran.'' XXIV:5 (May 1916), p. 128.] Accessed 2013-11-01.</ref> At the Savannah convention of 1914, the delegates agreed to pay Ezekiel a total of $8,229 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|8229|1914}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars) above the $40,000 already sent to him.{{efn|This figure included the $1,770.92 already paid to Ezekiel, plus another $6,459—the sum expended on shipping, site preparation, construction of the foundation, construction of the base, and erection of the statue. It is unclear why the delegates felt Ezekiel should receive $6,459, as he had not paid for these items.}} Savannah convention raised just $1,503.75 toward this sum, and the UDC general treasury donated another $1,000 from its treasury.<ref name="CV128" /> Moses Ezekiel died in March 1917, and it is unclear whether the UDC ever paid the outstanding $3,955.25 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|3955.25|1914}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars).
At the November 1917 UDC convention in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], the ACMA treasurer reported that the Confederate Memorial fund now showed a deficit of $1,325.25 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|1325.25|1917}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars). There is no indication in the UDC convention minutes as to why this deficit was incurred. The organization's treasurer proposed that the necessary funds be raised by donations at the convention and that any remaining deficit paid for by the UDC out of its treasury.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=sn8VAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Arlington%20Monument%22%20%22Confederate%20Veteran%22&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q=%22Arlington%20Monument%22%20%22Confederate%20Veteran%22&f=false United Daughters of the Confederacy, ''Minutes of the Twenty-Fourth Annual Convention...'', p. 71-72.] Accessed 2013-10-30.</ref>
===Burials at the memorial=== [[File:Confederate Monument - Marcus Wright grave - Arlington National Cemetery - 2011.JPG|thumb|Grave of Brig. Gen. Marcus J. Wright on the south side of the memorial.]] Burials in the Confederate section continued after the Confederate Memorial was completed. The first of these was Thomas Findley, who was buried on June 11, 1914, just days after the dedication ceremony. His interment, however, proved controversial because the War Department gave him [[Military funerals in the United States|full military honors]].<ref>"Burial First of Kind." ''Washington Post.'' June 12, 1914.</ref> This created widespread anger nationally among GAR members because Findley was not honorably discharged from the armed forces of the United States, as required by law.<ref>"Burial Rites Illegal." ''Washington Post.'' June 14, 1914.</ref>
Four notable burials occurred at the compass points of the Confederate Memorial, and stand out from the rest of the graves nearby for not being part of the concentric circles of burials. These are the graves of Moses Ezekiel, Lieutenant Harry C. Marmaduke, Captain John M. Hickey, and Brigadier General Marcus J. Wright.<ref name="ArlingtonNatCem" /> The first of these burials was that of Moses Ezekiel, which occurred on March 30, 1921. Ezekiel died in Italy on March 27, 1917. He requested that his body be brought back to the United States for burial, but this was not possible as World War I prevented it. His body was returned to America after the war and a funeral held in [[Arlington Memorial Amphitheater]] on March 30, 1921—the first funeral ever to be held in the year-old structure.<ref>"Impressive Rites for Moses Ezekiel." ''Washington Post.'' March 31, 1921; Peters, p. 78-79; Jacob, p. 171.</ref> His body was buried on the east side of the memorial, and a small granite pedestal surmounted by a bronze plaque placed at the head of the grave.
The second of the four notable burials was that of Brigadier General Wright, which occurred on December 29, 1922.<ref>"Gen. Wright Funeral Today." ''Washington Post.'' December 29, 1922.</ref> He was interred on the south side of the memorial. The third burial was that of Captain Henry H. Marmaduke, the last known surviving officer of the [[ironclad warship]] [[CSS Virginia|CSS ''Virginia'']] (which famously fought the {{USS|Monitor}} in the [[Battle of Hampton Roads]] on March 9, 1862). A [[Midshipman#United States Navy from 1845|midshipman]] at the time of the battle, he lived in the District of Columbia after 1883 and was buried on the west side of the memorial on November 17, 1924.<ref>"Last Monitor Merrimac Officer, 82, Dies Here." ''Washington Post.'' November 16, 1924.</ref> The last notable burial was that of Captain John M. Hickey, who was buried on the memorial's north side on October 3, 1927.<ref>"Capt. John J. Hickey Funeral Tomorrow." ''Washington Post.'' October 2, 1927.</ref>
It is unclear why these four were buried next to the memorial and not elsewhere in the Confederate section. Ezekiel, Wright, and Hickey all played major roles in creating the Confederate section and bringing the memorial into being, but it is less clear why Marmaduke warranted burial at the foot of the memorial (although his notable war service may have justified it). Also unclear is why no other notable burials occurred next to the memorial.
===Other history of the memorial=== The Confederate Memorial is the focus of Confederate Memorial Day exercises in the Washington, D.C., area. President Woodrow Wilson attended the first four events (1915, 1916, 1917, and 1918) held at the memorial, although he spoke at none of them.{{efn|It is unclear if Wilson was to speak at the 1915 event, as it was rained out. He attended but did not speak at the other three events. Wilson's presence in 1919, 1920, and 1921 was excused by the press of business due to World War I. See: "Unveil Southern Cross." ''Washington Post''. June 14, 1915; "Honor South's Valor." ''Washington Post''. June 5, 1916; "Dixie's War Spirit Ablaze for Country." ''Washington Post''. June 4, 1917; "Honor South's Heroes." ''Washington Post''. June 10, 1918; "South's Memorial Day at Arlington." ''Washington Post''. June 8, 1919; "Hundreds Extol South's Warriors." ''Washington Post''. June 7, 1920; "'Southern Cross' Unveiled at Arlington." ''Washington Post''. June 6, 1921.}} It is unclear when Wilson began sending wreaths to the event, although historians agree the tradition began with Wilson.<ref name="SonsofOldSouth" /> President [[Warren G. Harding]] spoke at the first Confederate Memorial Day event of his presidency in 1922,<ref>"Tells Confederates Reunion Is Complete." ''Washington Post''. June 5, 1922.</ref> but did not attend in 1923.<ref>"South's Cause Again Lauded." ''Washington Post''. June 4, 1923.</ref> Harding's successor, [[Calvin Coolidge]], spoke at the memorial on Confederate Memorial Day in 1924 (held that year on May 25).<ref>"President to Lead Services Today for Confederate Dead." ''Washington Post''. May 25, 1924.</ref> Coolidge sent a wreath beginning with the 1925 Confederate Memorial Day, but never again attended the event.<ref>"President Honors Confederate Dead at Arlington Rites." ''Washington Post''. May 26, 1924; "Graves of Wearers of Gray Decorated By War Comrades." ''Washington Post''. June 7, 1926; "Confederates' Sons Pay Tribute to Dead." ''Washington Post''. May 18, 1927.</ref><ref name="Honored600">"Confederate War Dead Honored By 600 at Arlington." ''Washington Post''. June 8, 1925.</ref> President Herbert Hoover never attended the event.<ref>"Hoover Speech to Honor Dead Heroes Today." ''Washington Post''. May 30, 1929; "Hoover Makes Please for Unity at Gettysburg." ''Washington Post''. May 31, 1930.</ref><ref name="ArlingtonService">"Arlington Service Held in Tribute to Confederate Dead." ''Washington Post''. June 8, 1931.</ref><ref name="ConfedRites">"2,000 at Memorial Confederate Rites." ''Washington Post''. June 6, 1932.</ref>
Attendance at the Confederate Memorial Day event at the memorial has fluctuated wildly. For example, more than 2,000 attended Confederate Memorial Day ceremonies at the memorial in 1912,<ref name="RosesFor" /> but just 600 did so in 1925 (the 60th anniversary of the end of the war).<ref name="Honored600" /> "Several hundred" attended the 1931 event,<ref name="ArlingtonService" /> while more than 2,000 came in 1932.<ref name="ConfedRites" /> A thousand were there in 1934.<ref>"Spirit of South Nation's Need, Veterans Told." ''Washington Post''. June 4, 1934.</ref> Although media coverage of the event was sparse in the 1930s, more than a thousand people attended the 1942 ceremony.<ref>"Thousand Pay Tribute to Confederate Dead." ''Washington Post''. June 8, 1942.</ref> Just 500 attended in 1946,<ref>"Confederate Memorial Rites Recall Glamour of Old South." ''Washington Post''. June 3, 1946.</ref> 400 in 1948,<ref>"Hoey Cites Rights Also of Majorities." ''Washington Post''. June 7, 1948.</ref> and 200 in 1951.<ref>"Tribute Paid To Memory of Confederacy." ''Washington Post''. June 18, 1951.</ref> About 150 people attended the 2007 event.<ref name="Wheeler" />
Graves in the Confederate section received new headstones in 1930.<ref>"Improvements Provided In Arlington Cemetery." ''Washington Post''. January 7, 1930.</ref>
[[File:Confederate Memorial Day services - Confederate Memorial - Arlington National Cemetery - 1922-06-05.jpg|thumb|left|Conclusion of the Confederate Memorial Day exercises in 1922. Note the much different landscaping around the memorial compared to photos from the 2000s, the still-extant sidewalks, and the far fewer graves.]] Another set of memorials was proposed for the Confederate section in 1931. The idea was sparked by a controversy over the burial of LaSalle Corbell Pickett, wife of [[General officers in the Confederate States Army#Major general|Major General]] [[George Pickett]] (CSA). Pickett died in [[Norfolk, Virginia]], on July 30, 1875.<ref>Brown, p. 730.</ref> After a brief interment in a cemetery in Norfolk,<ref>Selcer, p. 54.</ref> his remains were reburied in the Confederate military section of [[Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)|Hollywood Cemetery]] in [[Richmond, Virginia]], on October 24, 1875.<ref>"The Late Gen. Pickett." ''New York Times''. October 25, 1875.</ref> LaSalle Corbell Pickett died on March 22, 1931. Her wish was to be buried next to her husband, but Hollywood Cemetery officials refused, citing regulations that only men could be buried in the Confederate section of Hollywood Cemetery.<ref>"Burial of Pickett Widow Is Refused in Richmond." ''Washington Post''. March 25, 1931.</ref> Mrs. Pickett's grandson and eldest surviving male descendant, Lieutenant George E. Pickett III, was outraged by the cemetery's decision. He sought to have his grandmother buried in the Confederate section of Arlington National Cemetery, and have his grandfather's remains disinterred and brought to D.C. for burial beside her. Lieutenant Pickett then conferred with representatives of the War Department and Colonel Robert Lee Longstreet, son of [[General officers in the Confederate States Army#Lieutenant general|Lieutenant General]] [[James Longstreet]]. The three parties devised a plan to erect statues to Generals Pickett, Longstreet, and Robert E. Lee in the Confederate section.<ref>"Confederates Plan Arlington Shrine." ''Washington Post''. March 29, 1931.</ref> The three statues would be grouped together where Jackson Circle and McPherson Drive met, creating what Pickett and Longstreet called a "tri-hero corner". Additionally, Longstreet conceived of a site adjacent to the Confederate section where Confederates could be buried or reburied, and additional memorials to them erected. He brought his idea to War Department shortly after the tri-hero corner concept was broached.<ref name="DeadLostCause">"Dead of Lost Cause May Get U.S. Shrine." ''Washington Post''. March 30, 1931.</ref> Alarmed not only at the loss of Pickett's remains but at a potential shift in focus from Richmond to Arlington, Hollywood Cemetery officials quickly agreed to inter Mrs. Pickett next to her husband. With this decision, the rationale for a tri-hero corner largely went away, and neither it nor Longstreet's memorial section plan were implemented.<ref name="DeadLostCause" />
There were also attempts to erect additional Confederate memorials at Arlington National Cemetery in the 1930s. The first if these was a legislative proposal by Representative [[Hamilton Fish III]] in 1935 to erect a statue of Robert E. Lee somewhere in the cemetery.<ref name="Oppose">"Women Oppose Statue of Lee In Arlington." ''Washington Post''. May 16, 1935.</ref> The UDC had previously sought to erect a statue of Lee near [[Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial|Arlington House]] about 1900, but abandoned this plan to pursue the Confederate Memorial. The UDC strongly backed the Fish bill, but the legislation generated widespread opposition and died in Congress in 1936 without being acted on.<ref name="Oppose" /><ref>"G.A.R. Opposes Lee Memorial At Arlington." ''Washington Post''. September 25, 1936.</ref> A second Confederate memorial was proposed for Arlington Memorial Amphitheater. It is unclear who or what group made the suggestion (although the ''Washington Post'' implied it was a project of the Sons of Confederate Veterans), but it was proposed to inscribe the names of leading Confederate figures on the columns on either side of the apse in Memorial Amphitheater.<ref name="EyebrowsLifted" /> These square [[pilasters]] on either side of the apse list the names of famous American generals (left, as one faces the stage) and admirals (right) from the [[American Revolutionary War]] through the [[Spanish–American War]] of 1898.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=raVaAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Memorial%20Amphitheater%22%20Arlington%20exhibition%20hall&pg=PA94#v=onepage&q=%22Memorial%20Amphitheater%22%20Arlington%20exhibition%20hall&f=false "The Arlington Memorial Amphitheater." ''Architectural Forum''. January 1921, p. 94.] Accessed 2013-05-13.</ref> When the UDC learned of the proposal, many of its members wanted to add the names of Robert E. Lee and [[Stonewall Jackson|Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson]] to the columns as well. A resolution to this effect was offered at the UDC convention in 1937. However, delegates amended the resolution on the floor to deny UDC support for the changes unless the name of Confederate President [[Jefferson Davis]] was added as well. The resolution was then adopted.<ref name="EyebrowsLifted">"Eyebrows Lifted Over New Names At Amphitheater." ''Washington Post''. November 13, 1937.</ref> But only Congress had the authority to change the pilasters, and no legislation to add names was ever introduced.
Confederate Memorial Day ceremonies moved to Arlington Memorial Amphitheater from the Confederate Memorial in 1936. Although wreath layings and other brief ceremonies were still conducted at the base of the memorial, most of the event was held in the amphitheater.<ref>"Reynolds Says Confederacy's Spirit Lives On." ''Washington Post''. June 8, 1936</ref><ref>"Confederates Honor Dead At Arlington." ''Washington Post''. June 6, 1938</ref><ref>"New South Rising, Pepper Says At Confederate Day Services." ''Washington Post''. June 5, 1939</ref><ref>"Confederate Veterans, at Arlington Rites, Hear Leader and Sen. Hill Assail Hitler." ''Washington Post''. June 3, 1940.</ref><ref name="Radio">"Boys in Gray Pay Tribute To Their Dead." ''Washington Post''. June 7, 1937.</ref> The ceremonies from the amphitheater (but not the memorial) were first broadcast on radio by [[NBC]] in 1937.<ref name="Radio" /> The ceremonies moved back to the Confederate Memorial in 1941,<ref>Hart, Scott. "South's Sacrifices Can Teach Lesson Now, Gray Service Told." ''Washington Post''. June 2, 1941.</ref> but returned to the amphitheater in 1942.<ref>"Thousand Pay Tribute to Confederate Dead." ''Washington Post''. June 8, 1942.</ref> More recent ceremonies in the 1990s and 2000s have been at the Confederate Memorial, although it is unclear when the event moved out of Memorial Amphitheater. Former [[United States Secretary of the Navy|Secretary of the Navy]] [[Jim Webb]] spoke at a Confederate Memorial Day exercise at the memorial on June 3, 1990.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2015/06/24/jim-webb-draws-criticism-for-comments-on-confederate-flag/|last=Rappeport|first=Alan|title=Jim Webb Criticized for Comments on Confederate Flag|work=The New York Times|date=June 25, 2015|accessdate=June 25, 2015|postscript=none}}; {{cite web|url=http://www.jameswebb.com/speeches-by-jim/remarks-at-the-confederate-memorial|last=Webb|first=Jim|title=Remarks at the Confederate Memorial|website=JamesWebb.com|date=June 3, 1990|accessdate=June 25, 2015}}</ref>
In 2010, the Confederate Memorial made its first known appearance in a work of fiction. It was mentioned prominently in author [[Alice Randall]]'s 2010 novel ''Rebel Yell'', in which two African American characters discuss the inclusion of black slaves in the memorial's imagery and the confusion and meaning it has for African Americans today.<ref>Randall, Alice. ''Rebel Yell: A Novel''. New York: Bloomsbury, 2010, p. 135.</ref>
[[File:Maryland Sons of Confederate Veterans color guard 04 - Confederate Memorial Day - Arlington National Cemetery - 2014.jpg|thumb|A color guard provided by the Maryland Division of the Sons of Confederate Veterans retires the colors on June 8, 2014, during Confederate Memorial Day exercises commemorating the 100th anniversary of the memorials' dedication.]] The 100th anniversary of the dedication of the Confederate Memorial was noted with a ceremony on Confederate Memorial Day hosted by the United Daughters of the Confederacy on June 8, 2014.
===Recent controversies about the memorial=== Beginning with Woodrow Wilson in 1919, almost every President of the United States sent a wreath to the Confederate Memorial Day exercises.<ref name="SonsofOldSouth" /> This tradition was broken by President [[Harry S. Truman]] in 1949 and again in 1950.<ref name="SonsofOldSouth">"Sons of Old South Resent Truman's Wreath Omission." ''Washington Post.'' June 5, 1950.</ref> Truman resumed the tradition in 1951, and a presidential wreath continued to be donated each year for the next four decades.<ref name="DayMarked">[http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post_now/post/confederate-memorial-day-marked-at-arlington/2011/06/05/AGo3yZJH_blog.html "Confederate Memorial Day Marked at Arlington." ''Associated Press .'' June 5, 2011.] Accessed 2013-06-23.</ref> In 1990, President [[George H. W. Bush]] declined to send a wreath to the ceremony, citing infighting among Confederate groups.<ref>York, Anthony. "Confederates in the Attic." Salon.com. December 20, 2002.</ref> Bush declined to send a wreath again in 1991 and 1992. But President [[Bill Clinton]] resumed the tradition in 1993,<ref>McCaslin, John. "Wreaths For All." ''Washington Times.'' May 29, 2003.</ref> and it was continued by his successor, President [[George W. Bush]].<ref name="DayMarked" />
When African American Senator [[Barack Obama]] became President in November 2008, he faced a dilemma about continuing the tradition. As Kirk Savage, art historian, put it, "a black president suddenly became in charge of a tradition steeped in white supremacy".<ref name="Savage183" /> In 2009, several dozen university professors and historians asked President Obama to end the tradition,<ref name="DayMarked" /> and the issue received some mass media attention. Confederate heritage groups denounced any attempt to end the presidential wreath tradition, arguing it would be an insult to Southerners. A few days before the 2009 Confederate Memorial Day, Savage argued in a ''Washington Post'' editorial that the Southerners were essentially correct. He concluded that to end the tradition would only reinforce racist attitudes in America and do little to promote an understanding of the role of slavery in American history and society.<ref name="Savage183" /> President Obama himself never addressed the issue.<ref name="Savage183" /> Instead, Obama sent a wreath not only to the Confederate Memorial but also instituted a new tradition of sending a presidential wreath to the [[African American Civil War Memorial]] in Washington, D.C.<ref name="DayMarked" />
